body.p: To create your first XML document, choose File New... . The New Document Wizard is displayed:

You can either create a new XML document from scratch by choosing one of available types in the New Document folder, or you can choose to create one from a template by choosing a template from the Global templates or Framework templates folders. If you are looking for a commone document types such as DITA or DocBook, you will find templates for these document types in the Framewrork templates folder. If your company has created its own templates, your will also find them here.

For some document types, you may find a number of different templates. For example, there are a number of different templates for different DocBook documents, and for different DITA topic types and maps. Choose the template that best meets your needs.

section.title: Writing your first document
section.p: Depending on the type of document you choose, the interface will change to support editing that document type. This may include new menus, new toolbar buttons, and new items on the context menus.

Also, depending on the type of document you choose, may have opened your document in Text or Author mode. Text mode shows the raw XML source file. Author mode shows a graphical view of the document. Whether there is an Author mode view avaialble for your document type depends on what type you choose and whether there is an Author mode style sheet avaialble to create the Author view. supplies default Author mode views for most of the document types it supports. If your company has created its own document types, it may also have create Author mode stylesheets for that type. However, if you chose to create a plain XML file, or to create one based on a schema for which has not built in support, you will have to edit in in Text mode or create your own Author mode style sheet for it.

You can switch back and forth between Author mode and Text mode at any time by clicking the buttons at the bottom right of the editor window. You won't lose any formatting when switching from Author to Text mode. Text and Author mode are just different views on the same XML document. (There is also a Grid mode available, which is useful for certain kinds of documents, particularly those that are structured like databases.)

If you are using Author mode, you will find that it works a lot like whatever word processor you are used to. If you are using Text mode, you will find it works a lot like many typical text editors. The biggest difference you will find, if you are new to XML, is that XML documents have a particular structure that you have to follow.

section.title: Structuring your first document
section.p: Each XML document type has a particular structure that you have to follow. Some document types give you a lot of choices. Some give you very few. In either case, however, you need to make sure that your XML follows that allowed structure for the document type you are creating. This means:

ul.li: At any given point in the document, there are only certain XML elements allowed. helps you determine which elemets are allowed.

When you create certain elemens, you may find that your text gets a red underline and you get a warning that you content is invalid. This is usually because the element you have just created requires certain other elements inside it. Your document will be invalid until you create those elements. ( will do its best to help you with this. If there is only one possible element that can go inside the element you just created, will create it for you. If there is more than one possiblity, though, you will have to create the content yourself.

section.title: Editing your first document
section.p: Once you have completed the first draft of your document, you may need to edit it. As with any editor, provides the normal cut, copy, and paste options as well as drag and drop editing. However, when you are editing an XML document, you have to make sure that your edits respect the structure of the XML document type. In fact, you are often editing the structure as well as the content of your document.
provides many tools to help you edit your structure and to keep your structure correct when editing text.

section.title: Validating your first document
section.p: Validation is the process of checking that an XML document obeyes the rules of its schema. If knows how to find the schema, it will validate the document for you as you type. ( can find the schema automatically for most of the document types created from templates. In some cases, though, you may have to tell it how to find the schema.)

When validates as you type, there is a small bar at the right edge of the editor that tells you if the document is valid, and where in the document any errors are found. If the indicator at the top of that bar is green, your document is invalid. If the document is invalid, the indicator turns red and a red bar shows you where in the document the error was found. Click on that bar to jump to the error. Remember that sometimes your document is invalid simply because the structure you are creating is not complete yet. If cannot find one of the resources it needs to validate a document, the validity indicator will turn yellow.
You can also validate your document at any time by clicking the Validate button or choosing Document Validate...
